bibl.title: Letter fragment to Albert E. Truby, July 15, 1936

div1.p: The writer urges Truby to place his yellow fever correspondence in an archive for safekeeping and compliments Kean personally and professionally.

div1.head: Letter fragment to Albert E. Truby, July 15, 1936
div1.opener:
1870 Wyoming Avenue,
Washington, D.C.,
July 15, 1936
FROM GEN. ALBERT E. TRUBY
My dear Truby,
div1.p:
Thank you very much for the interest you took about Trans-
America. I not only received a letter with all the data I wanted but
they put me in touch with the firm here in Washington which handles that
stock. I am very much pleased with conditions as they are now and I have
no fear whatever but that I am going to come out more than all right with
my 524 shares. Isn't it too bad that poor old Kennedy could not have saved
some of the stock that he made his fortune in? I think one of the greatest
assets of Trans-America is A. P. Gianinne. I hope the Good Lord will let
him live to a ripe old age. He saved the entire institution by coming back
into the business after the New York crowd of financiers had practically
put it on the rocks.

I have had a couple of talks with Hitch and he has been around to
see Judge Pollard, the Chairman of the Board. The answer is exactly the
same as it was six months ago--none resign, few die and Hitch made another
observation this morning to the effect that they are all looking remarkably
well. I am sorry. I would love it if you and Mrs. Truby could come back
here. Then we would have the opportunity to see you and play with you both.

I have not seen either one of your daughters since we returned June
16th but Richard LaGarde, who is here in the room, says that they are both
fine. He saw them on Sunday.

Kean was nice enough to show me the correspondence you have had about
the yellow fever work in Cuba. That is historic and should be placed
where it will be available. You were so quiet about the thing that I never
knew you were mixed up in it until you let loose one day when you were in
my office. Kean intends to have your letter filed with the rest of the
records. It is needless for me to say that I agree with you in everything
you say about Kean, one of the most charming men that I ever knew with a
constructive mind who did constructive work for the Medical Corps of the
Army that will last as long as the Corps lasts. There was just some ele-
ment in Kean's make-up that did not permit him to arrive. He was just
within grasp of the Surgeon Generalcy on several occasions. The President
had told a dozen people that he was going to make Kean Surgeon General and
when the time came he didn't do it. That was when General O'Reilly went
out.

Yesterday I telephoned to Kean and told him I would come to get him
at 11 o'clock today and that we would then go to see Colonel Coe and then
have lunch at the Club. We are going to take Lynch with us. Kean was just
on the point of telephoning to me to the effect that Mrs. Coe had had a
cerebral hemorrhage the day before and was in the Garfield Hospital. It may
be that we will have to go over there to see Coe. I am sorry, of course,
but since it has happened I hope the end will not be long delayed. You
probably know that she is disabled on account of the fracture of the hip
